pr_title: feat(iot-dev): Fix multiplexing client not reporting unauthorized exceptions

timeline.message:
feat(iot-dev): Fix multiplexing client not reporting unauthorized exceptions

Previously, if a device client registered to the multiplexing client had an out of date connection string, the register call would block infinitely. Now the method will throw an exception instead.

This also adds an optional timeout to the registration/unregistration APIs to allow users to have shorter or longer timeouts than our new default of 1 minute.

Note that this also changes the thrown exceptions of most of the multiplexing client APIs. This is fine since this feature is in preview.

feat(iot-dev): Fix multiplexing client not reporting unauthorized exceptions

Previously, if a device client registered to the multiplexing client had an out of date connection string, the register call would block infinitely. Now the method will throw an exception instead.

This also adds an optional timeout to the registration/unregistration APIs to allow users to have shorter or longer timeouts than our new default of 1 minute.

Note that this also changes the thrown exceptions of most of the multiplexing client APIs. This is fine since this feature is in preview.

timeline.bodyText: We did this silly thing in the DeviceClient to work around the fact that we can't throw TransportException's directly in methods like deviceClient.open() becuase the open API existed before the TransportException did. To get around it, we just nested the meaningful exception into an IOException. I don't want to do the same thing for the multiplexing client though, so this code un-nests the exception when possible.

replies.bodyText: MultiplexingClientException is the super type of MultiplexingClientDeviceRegistrationFailedException here. Normally I'd only call out that the method throws the super type, since that is all that Javadocs require, but it felt useful to call out MultiplexingClientDeviceRegistrationFailedException in particular as it can be handled differently from MultiplexingClientException. The more specific exception has a map of deviceId->registration exception that users can read when reacting to such exceptions.

You can't register a device client that has already been opened, whether it was opened on a different multiplexing client, or just opened as a non-multiplexing client connection.

should this say "and then will block until the device client has been opened"

I'm deliberately trying to use the phrase "register" rather than "open" in this context since the API itself is called "registerDeviceClient"

replies.bodyText:
On that note, what happens if I call deviceClient.close() but don't unregister the client from the mux connection. Will it just hang around in the connection blocking one position? If I call deviceClient.open() after that, will it be usable again?

I have a special UnsupportedOperationException to prevent users from calling open/close on the device client itself when the client is multiplexed. The only way to open and close a multiplexed client is by registering it/unregistering it

I see this note below: "It cannot be used in non-multiplexing scenarios", so will deviceclient.close() throw an exception?

Yep. That way users can't mix up if their client is multiplexed or not

replies.bodyText:
The message will be a hardcoded "Timed out waiting for all device unregistrations to finish." and there will not be a nested throwable, at least for now. The only reason I provide overloaded constructors that take throwables is because that is standard for exceptions.

does it give any info about which device actually timed out

No, because this timeout is for all of the device registrations, not per device registration. If a user calls the singular multiplexingClient.registerDeviceClient(), then they will know which client timed out. For the bulk APIs, though, I expect users will just call the API again with the same set of device clients to be registered. The multiplexing client allows for you to "re-register" a client or a set of clients without throwing, after all.
